articles.headline: Trump Administration Returns Copies of Report on C.I.A. Torture to Congress
articles.snippet: The move raises the possibility that the few existing copies of the 6,700-page report could be locked in Senate vaults and never made public.
articles.abstract: The move raises the possibility that the few existing copies of the 6,700-page report could be locked in Senate vaults and never made public.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senators, spies and a president spent years in a pitched battle over how the history is told of one of the most controversial chapters of America’s campaign against terrorism, the detention and interrogation of prisoners in secret C.I.A. jails.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Matthew Rosenberg and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: India, Once a Coal Goliath, Is Fast Turning Green
articles.snippet: As the United States drops out of the Paris climate pact, New Delhi is canceling coal-fired power plants and investing heavily in renewable energy sources.
articles.abstract: As the United States drops out of the Paris climate pact, New Delhi is canceling coal-fired power plants and investing heavily in renewable energy sources.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — Just a few years ago, the world watched nervously as India went on a building spree of coal-fired power plants, more than doubling its capacity and claiming that more were needed. Coal output, officials said, would almost triple, to 1.5 billion tons, by 2020.

articles.headline: Does Donald Trump Still Think Climate Change Is a Hoax? No One Can Say
articles.snippet: No one working for President Trump who was sent out to explain his decision on the Paris accords knows or would say if he believes in climate change.
articles.abstract: No one working for President Trump who was sent out to explain his decision on the Paris accords knows or would say if he believes in climate change.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As a businessman, President Trump was a frequent and scornful critic of the concept of climate change. In the years before running for president, he called it “nonexistent,” “mythical” and a “a total con job.” Whenever snow fell in New York, it seemed, he would mock the idea of global warming.

articles.headline: Fringe Groups Revel as Protests Turn Violent
articles.snippet: Far-right groups recruit mainly young white men for confrontations with their ideological enemies — left-wing activists protesting against conservative speakers on college campuses.
articles.abstract: Far-right groups recruit mainly young white men for confrontations with their ideological enemies — left-wing activists protesting against conservative speakers on college campuses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kyle Chapman expected he might find a fight. And he did — with a teenage girl.
articles.byline: By Alan Feuer and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Apple Piles On the Features, and Users Say, ‘Enough!’
articles.snippet: The company will show off new features for the iPhone and other products on Monday, but customers are still struggling to get comfortable with the last round of improvements.
articles.abstract: The company will show off new features for the iPhone and other products on Monday, but customers are still struggling to get comfortable with the last round of improvements.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As Apple prepares to show off new features for the iPhone and other devices at its developer conference on Monday, the company is grappling with an uncomfortable issue: Many of its existing features are already too complicated for many users to figure out.

articles.headline: Small Businesses Cheer ‘New Sheriff in Town’ After Climate Pact Exit
articles.snippet: Local firms’ leaders around the country remain widely supportive of President Trump, even as some chief executives of big corporations pull away.
articles.abstract: Local firms’ leaders around the country remain widely supportive of President Trump, even as some chief executives of big corporations pull away.
articles.lead_paragraph: As news that President Trump was pulling out of the Paris climate accord hit at a luncheon for small-business owners in Toledo, Ohio, on Thursday, an already happy crowd suddenly turned euphoric.

articles.headline: Here’s How a Chinese Tech Firm Borrowed $2.1 Billion in a Hurry
articles.snippet: Stumbling after it got overextended, LeEco was still able to raise billions of dollars from shadowy lenders and from investors large and small.
articles.abstract: Stumbling after it got overextended, LeEco was still able to raise billions of dollars from shadowy lenders and from investors large and small.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a Chinese tech company with global ambitions began to run short of cash last year, it sought billions of dollars from new investors. One of them was a music teacher.

articles.headline: Dissecting Marissa Mayer’s $900,000-a-Week Yahoo Paycheck
articles.snippet: Yahoo’s chief executive presided over the decline and sale of the company. But she delivered big rewards to investors.
articles.abstract: Yahoo’s chief executive presided over the decline and sale of the company. But she delivered big rewards to investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When a withered Yahoo is absorbed by Verizon Communications in the next week or so, it will be the end of an era for one of the pioneering names of the internet age.

articles.headline: The Doctor Is In. Co-Pay? $40,000.
articles.snippet: For five-figure annual fees, boutique medical services offer the wealthiest Americans the chance to cut the line and receive the best treatment.
articles.abstract: For five-figure annual fees, boutique medical services offer the wealthiest Americans the chance to cut the line and receive the best treatment.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When John Battelle’s teenage son broke his leg at a suburban soccer game, naturally the first call his parents made was to 911. The second was to Dr. Jordan Shlain, the concierge doctor here who treats Mr. Battelle and his family.

articles.headline: ‘Last Secret’ of 1967 War: Israel’s Doomsday Plan for Nuclear Display
articles.snippet: Israel was ready to detonate an atomic device on a Sinai mountain as a warning if it looked as if it were losing, newly released interviews reveal.
articles.abstract: Israel was ready to detonate an atomic device on a Sinai mountain as a warning if it looked as if it were losing, newly released interviews reveal.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the eve of the Arab-Israeli war, 50 years ago this week, Israeli officials raced to assemble an atomic device and developed a plan to detonate it atop a mountain in the Sinai Peninsula as a warning to Egyptian and other Arab forces, according to an interview with a key organizer of the effort that will be published Monday.
articles.byline: By William J. Broad and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: How G.O.P. Leaders Came to View Climate Change as Fake Science
articles.snippet: The party’s fast journey from debating how to combat climate change to arguing against its existence is a story of big political money and Democratic hubris.
articles.abstract: The party’s fast journey from debating how to combat climate change to arguing against its existence is a story of big political money and Democratic hubris.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The campaign ad appeared during the presidential contest of 2008. Rapid-fire images of belching smokestacks and melting ice sheets were followed by a soothing narrator who praised a candidate who had stood up to President George W. Bush and “sounded the alarm on global warming.”
articles.byline: By Coral Davenport and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: The Single-Payer Party? Democrats Shift Left on Health Care
articles.snippet: Liberal Democrats have pressed lawmakers to support a single-payer health care system, and strident supporters say the party has moved further left on the issue.
articles.abstract: Liberal Democrats have pressed lawmakers to support a single-payer health care system, and strident supporters say the party has moved further left on the issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, Republicans savaged Democrats for supporting the Affordable Care Act, branding the law — with some rhetorical license — as a government takeover of health care.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Jennifer Medina

articles.headline: Obama’s Dilemma on Troop Surge in Afghanistan Now Vexes Trump
articles.snippet: The numbers under consideration are more modest than in 2009, but like his predecessor, President Trump confronts a divide between his generals and his aides.
articles.abstract: The numbers under consideration are more modest than in 2009, but like his predecessor, President Trump confronts a divide between his generals and his aides.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A new president confronts an old war, one that bedeviled his predecessor. He is caught between seasoned military commanders, who tell him that the road to victory is to pour in more American troops, and skeptical political advisers, who argue that a major deployment is a futile exercise that will leave him politically vulnerable.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Another Terrorist Attack Strikes the Heart of London
articles.snippet: Six civilians were killed and 48 were hospitalized in attacks near London Bridge in what both Prime Minister Theresa May and the police called an act of terror.
articles.abstract: Six civilians were killed and 48 were hospitalized in attacks near London Bridge in what both Prime Minister Theresa May and the police called an act of terror.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Another night of terrorism unfolded in Britain on Saturday with two attacks that killed six civilians in the center of the capital, London police said.

articles.headline: After London Attack, Prime Minister Says, ‘Enough Is Enough’
articles.snippet: After at least seven civilians were killed and dozens injured in attacks near London Bridge, Prime Minister Theresa May vowed an overhaul of Britain’s counterterrorism policy.
articles.abstract: After at least seven civilians were killed and dozens injured in attacks near London Bridge, Prime Minister Theresa May vowed an overhaul of Britain’s counterterrorism policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Declaring “enough is enough,” Prime Minister Theresa May vowed on Sunday to conduct a sweeping review of Britain’s counterterrorism strategy after three knife-wielding assailants unleashed an assault late Saturday night, the third major terrorist attack in the country in three months.

articles.headline: Trump’s Off-the-Cuff Tweets Strain Foreign Ties
articles.snippet: After initial condolences, the president wasted little time in using the assault to defend his travel ban and attack the London mayor, widening a trans-Atlantic rift.
articles.abstract: After initial condolences, the president wasted little time in using the assault to defend his travel ban and attack the London mayor, widening a trans-Atlantic rift.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On one level, President Trump reacted to Saturday night’s terrorist attack in London much as his predecessors might have. He expressed solidarity and telephoned Britain’s prime minister to offer condolences. “WE ARE WITH YOU,” he wrote to Britons.

articles.headline: Sugar Talks May Hint at Trump Approach to U.S.-Mexico Trade
articles.snippet: Both sides have power to leverage in negotiations over Mexican sugar exports, talks that could set the tone for Nafta discussions.
articles.abstract: Both sides have power to leverage in negotiations over Mexican sugar exports, talks that could set the tone for Nafta discussions.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The sugar barons of Florida, Alfonso and José Fanjul, have been equal-opportunity political donors for decades, showering largess on the campaigns of Democrats and Republicans alike to ensure that lawmakers will protect the American sugar industry.

articles.headline: Outcry Over EpiPen Prices Hasn’t Made Them Lower
articles.snippet: Mylan has an effective monopoly on a lifesaving product, which has allowed its leaders to see public outrage as a tax they must pay.
articles.abstract: Mylan has an effective monopoly on a lifesaving product, which has allowed its leaders to see public outrage as a tax they must pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, after some particularly incompetent parenting on my part (nuts in the dessert, a rushed trip to an emergency room after my child’s allergic reaction), I visited the local pharmacy to fill an EpiPen prescription.

articles.headline: G.M. Wants to Drive the Future of Cars That Drive Themselves
articles.snippet: Under its chief executive, Mary T. Barra, General Motors is redirecting energy and capital toward a race with Silicon Valley to create self-driving cars.
articles.abstract: Under its chief executive, Mary T. Barra, General Motors is redirecting energy and capital toward a race with Silicon Valley to create self-driving cars.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The chief executive of General Motors, an automaker synonymous with Detroit, saw the future of driving not in the Motor City but on the streets of San Francisco.

articles.headline: Climate Science Meets a Stubborn Obstacle: Students
articles.snippet: A new teacher’s efforts to educate teenagers in Ohio coal country ran up against a cultural resistance to evidence of the human role in global warming.
articles.abstract: A new teacher’s efforts to educate teenagers in Ohio coal country ran up against a cultural resistance to evidence of the human role in global warming.
articles.lead_paragraph: WELLSTON, Ohio — To Gwen Beatty, a junior at the high school in this proud, struggling, Trump-supporting town, the new science teacher’s lessons on climate change seemed explicitly designed to provoke her.

articles.headline: ‘Wonder Woman’ Could Be the Superhero Women in Hollywood Need
articles.snippet: After a record-breaking weekend at the box office, the movie’s success suggests some welcome changes in the film industry. But progress has come too slowly.
articles.abstract: After a record-breaking weekend at the box office, the movie’s success suggests some welcome changes in the film industry. But progress has come too slowly.
articles.lead_paragraph: Something huge happened at the box office over the weekend.

articles.headline: Oculus Founder Plots a Comeback With a Virtual Border Wall
articles.snippet: After facing political criticism and leaving Facebook, Palmer Luckey is working on another start-up. Its military interest will go nicely with his helicopters and abandoned missile silos.
articles.abstract: After facing political criticism and leaving Facebook, Palmer Luckey is working on another start-up. Its military interest will go nicely with his helicopters and abandoned missile silos.
articles.lead_paragraph: Palmer Freeman Luckey was the kind of wunderkind Silicon Valley venerates. When he was just 21, he made an overnight fortune selling his start-up, a company called Oculus VR that made virtual-reality gear, to Facebook for $2 billion in 2014.

articles.headline: Bank at Center of U.S. Inquiry Projects Russian ‘Soft Power’
articles.snippet: VEB, whose chief met in December with Jared Kushner, President Trump’s son-in-law, is intertwined with the Russian state and intelligence services.
articles.abstract: VEB, whose chief met in December with Jared Kushner, President Trump’s son-in-law, is intertwined with the Russian state and intelligence services.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has offices in a sleek Manhattan skyscraper. Its bonds are accessible to millions of American investors. And it holds ties to some of New York’s biggest banks.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess, Andrew E. Kramer and Mike McIntire

articles.headline: 5 Arab Nations Move to Isolate Qatar, Putting the U.S. in a Bind
articles.snippet: The feud among regional allies of Washington threatens to stress the American-led campaign against ISIS and complicate efforts to confront Iran.
articles.abstract: The feud among regional allies of Washington threatens to stress the American-led campaign against ISIS and complicate efforts to confront Iran.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — For years, the tiny, energy-rich country of Qatar has carved out a niche in the Arab world by trying to be everything to everyone. It housed an American military base and flooded the region’s airwaves with its influential media, all while keeping close ties to Iran and a wide selection of Islamist movements.
articles.byline: By Anne Barnard and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Trump Promotes Original ‘Travel Ban,’ Eroding His Legal Case
articles.snippet: Rebelling against his own advisers, the president said his order should never have been “watered down” even as his lawyers try to persuade the Supreme Court to reinstate it.
articles.abstract: Rebelling against his own advisers, the president said his order should never have been “watered down” even as his lawyers try to persuade the Supreme Court to reinstate it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has excellent lawyers. They have a challenging client.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and Peter Baker

articles.headline: At Least One London Assailant Was on Police Radar, Exposing Gaps
articles.snippet: The third terrorist assault in Britain in three months has created the impression of a campaign, but officials say many more plots are thwarted.
articles.abstract: The third terrorist assault in Britain in three months has created the impression of a campaign, but officials say many more plots are thwarted.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain on Monday identified two of the three suspects in the weekend’s terrorist assault in London, including one who not only was well-known to the police but had a cameo in a television documentary on homegrown violent jihadists.

articles.headline: HomePod Speaker and New iMacs: What We Saw at Apple’s WWDC
articles.snippet: Apple held its annual developer conference, where it announced the brand new HomePod speaker, other hardware and updates to its operating systems.
articles.abstract: Apple held its annual developer conference, where it announced the brand new HomePod speaker, other hardware and updates to its operating systems.
articles.lead_paragraph: • Apple gave a sneak peek of HomePod, a speaker, to rival Amazon’s Echo and Google’s Home. It’s the first brand-new hardware product for Apple since the Apple Watch.
articles.byline: By Brian X. Chen, Farhad Manjoo and Vindu Goel
